column9: Description

1) Stand with your hands gently resting on a wall. 2) Cross your right foot in front of your left ankle (right calf contacting left shin). 3) The toes of your right foot should be pointing back behind you (top of your toes on the floor). 4) Bend both your knees, your back knee pushes your front knee forward and you should feel a stretch up the front of the right shin. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 6) Repeat other leg.

To stretch the right side: 1) Sit in a chair with both feet on the ground. 2) Cross the right ankle over onto the left knee. 3) Take hold of the right foot with both hands and face the sole of the foot up towards the ceiling, you should feel a stretch up the outside of the lower leg. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat on the leg and repeat again both sides.

1) Stand directly in front of a wall with elbows slightly bent and hands resting on the wall with your feet together. 2) Place your left foot a little in front of your right (half a foot) but still together. 3) Keeping your heels on the ground bend at both your knees, you should feel a stretch up the right Achilles and lower part of the calf. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds and then change sides. 5) Repeat.

column3: Strength for arch of foot and foot stabiliser
column9: 1) Stand with the inside of your left foot on the edge of a step and your right foot just stabilising. 2) Gently drop the inside of your foot down the step and hold for 10-20 seconds. 3) Come out of the position and rest then repeat after 10-20 seconds. 4) Repeat both sides.

column2: Alfredson's  heel-drop protocol for Achilles tendinopathy - gastrocnemius
column3: Alfredson's  rehabilitation method for Achilles tendinopathy
column9: 1) Stand on a small step or ledge with one leg flexed behind and the other on the ledge with leg straight on tip toes. 2) Hold onto a wall in front to assist your leg coming up from each exercise. 3) Lower your foot down on the ledge to level with the ledge (not below) and then come up using the wall or other leg to help. 3) Repeat 15 times. 4) Repeat with the knee flexed to 45 degrees.(* See related exercises - Alfredson's Soleus).  5) Repeat on the other leg if affected. 5) 3 sets each leg. 6) 2 times daily, 7 days a week for 12 weeks. *Note - There may be discomfort associated with this exercise, please contact your practitioner if you need further assistance.

column2: Alfredson's heel-drop protocol for Achilles tendinopathy - soleus
column3: Alfredson's  rehabilitation method for Achilles tendinopathy
column9: 1) Stand on a small step or ledge with one leg flexed behind and the other on the ledge with leg straight on tip toes* See Alfredson's gastrocnemius for picture. 2) Hold onto a wall in front to assist your leg coming up from each exercise. 3) Lower your foot down on the ledge to level with the ledge (not below) and then come up using the wall or other leg to help. 3) Repeat 15 times. 4) Repeat with the knee flexed to 45 degrees.  5) Repeat on the other leg if affected. 5) 3 sets each leg. 6) 2 times daily, 7 days a week for 12 weeks. *Note - There may be discomfort associated with this exercise, please contact your practitioner if you need further assistance. (See related exercises)

column3: Strength for ankle / leg using resistance band
column6: Post ankle / leg injury, walkers, runners
column9: 1) Sit on a chair or table so that your legs are dangling without touching the floor. 2) Place a resistance band around the ball of your foot and hold onto either end with firm resistance. 3) Point your toes down to the ground and then back to resting position. 4) Repeat 10-12 times. 5) Repeat on the other leg if needed.

column3: Strength for outside lower leg muscles
column6: Post ankle / leg injury, shin splints,
column9: 1) Sit on a chair or table so that your legs are dangling without touching the floor. 2) Place a resistance band around the ball of your foot and hold onto either end with firm resistance with the sole of your foot facing towards your other leg 3) Try to turn the sole of your foot away from your other leg and then back to resting position. 4) Repeat 10-12 times. 5) Repeat on the other leg if needed.

1) Sit on a chair or table so that your legs are dangling without touching the floor. 2) Move your right ankle around in a clockwise direction trying to localise the movement to your ankle (try not to let the hip and knee move too much). 3) Make the movements as large as possible in a pain free range. 4) Repeat 10 times in both directions. 5) Repeat other ankle.

1) Sit on a chair or table so that your legs are dangling without touching the floor. 2) Imagine you are writing the alphabet with your foot,  continue slowly and in a controlled manner (try not to let the hip and knee move too much). 3) Make the movements as large as possible in a pain free range. 4) Repeat other ankle.

1) Stand in front of a wall, hands on the wall for support, feet apart. 2) Take most of your body weight on the good leg. 3) Slowly rise up on your toes, hold for 5 seconds, relax down slowly. 4) Repeat 10 - 15 times.

column3: Hamstring (back of thigh) stretch using foam roller
column9: 1) Stand in front of a wall, hands on the wall for support, feet apart. 2) Take most of your body weight on the good leg. 3) Carefully rock back on your heels and lift up your toes. 4) Hold for 5 seconds. Relax down slowly. 5) Repeat 10 - 15 times.

column6: Post ankle / leg injury, stimulate proprioception
column9: 1) Stand on one leg, lifting the other leg up, and hold for up to a minute (as long as you can without losing balance). 2) Repeat 3 times. 3) When this becomes easy you can increase the challenge by closing your eyes and repeating the same exercise. 4) Increasing difficulty again, coming up onto tip toes.

1) Sit on a chair, put your foot flat on the ground. 2) Keep your heel on the ground but lift the front of your foot up off the ground. 3) Hold for 5 seconds then relax the foot down slowly. 4) Repeat 10-15 times.

column6: Leg and ankle strength, post leg / ankle injury, flattened feet
column9: 1) Using a corridor inside or grass outside of approximately 20m or so, barefoot. 2) Start by walking on the balls of your feet (tippy toes) one way and then walk back on your heels. 3) Repeat this 3-5 times.

column6: To stimulate proprioception / neural connections between the feet and brain
column9: 1) Walk on the beach barefoot! Very good for your proprioception and nerve endings in your feet.

1) Place a piece of A4 paper on the floor. 2) Place your bare foot in the centre of the piece of paper. 3) The aim is to scrunch the piece of paper in the area of the arch of your foot without scrunching the toes. 4) You are using the short foot muscles in your feet, and lifting the arch as you do this - it takes practise.  5) Repeat 10 times each side.

column3: Sole of foot (plantar fascia) self massage
column9: 1) Standing holding onto a sturdy table for support if needed. 2) Place the spiky ball under the arch of your foot and roll the ball back and forth increasing the pressure as able to tolerate. 3) Roll the ball for about 20-30 seconds each foot.

1) Standing with one foot up against a wall so that your toes and contacting the wall and your heel is on the ground. 2) Push your toes into the wall and your heel slightly away, you should feel a stretch in the sole of your foot. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat other foot.

column6: Runners, walkers, hikers starting out or increasing distances
column9: 1) Tie one end of the resistance band to a table leg. 2) Sit on a chair and wrap the other end around your forefoot with leg out straight, making sure there is good resistance with your toes pointing towards the table. 3) Move your toes up towards the ceiling, and then point towards the table. 4) Repeat 10-15 times. 5) Repeat other leg.
1) Stand on the edge of a step, slowly lower heels slightly below step and then come up onto tip toes. 2) Repeat 10-15 times.

1) Stand on the edge of a step with one foot with the other foot lifted off the step or ledge, knee flexed (hold onto a wall for support). 2) Slowly lower foot slightly below step and then come up onto tip toes. 2) Repeat 10-15 times.
1) Place 1-2 cups of epsom salts into a warm foot bath (bucket). 2) Soak feet for at least 20 minutes - ideally 30-40 minutes. 3) Helps with muscle tension and aching feet.

column7: Towel / strong resistance band / or strap
column9: 1) Lie on your back with your right hip and knee flexed to 90 degrees and a towel wrapped around your foot holding onto both ends with your hands. 2) Straighten up your right leg and at the same time turn the sole of your foot to the right (everting). 3) Then bend your leg back to 90 degrees at hip and knee. 4) Repeat 10 times.

column7: Towel / strong resistance band / or strap
column9: 1) Lie on your back with your right hip and knee flexed to 90 degrees and a towel wrapped around your foot holding onto both ends with your hands. 2) Take your right foot over to your left shoulder with a slight bend in the knee. 3) Straighten up your right leg and then bend at the knee. 4) You should feel a stretch when the leg is straight and then an ease when you bend the knee. 5) Repeat the bending and straightening 10 times. 6) Slowly bring the leg back down.

column6: Calf tightness, knee pain, runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Stand in front of a wall with both hands resting at shoulder level on the wall. 2) Place your left leg in front taking most of your body weight on this leg. 3) Place the right leg stretched far out behind you keeping the knee straight and only putting the ball of the foot on the ground. 4) Slowly bend the left knee and move your pelvis forward towards the wall. 5) Keeping the right knee straight gently push the right heel downwards until you feel a mild stretch high up in the calf. 6) Hold for 20-30 seconds, repeat x2 each sideYou can vary this stretch by rotating the heel out to the left of the toes and also to the right of the toes to feel the stretch in the outer and inner muscle fibres.

column6: Calf tightness, knee pain, runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Stand in front of a wall with both hands resting at shoulder level on the wall. 2) Place your right leg in front taking most of your body weight on this leg. 3) Place the left leg stretched far out behind you keeping the knee straight and only putting the ball of the foot on the ground. 4) Slowly bend the right knee and move your pelvis forward towards the wall. 5) Bend the left knee until you feel a stretch lower down in the calf (heel can lift off the ground) . 6) Hold for 20-30 seconds, repeat x2 each side.

column3: Calf (lower leg) stretch using foam roller
column9: 1) Sitting with the foam roller under both your calves. 2) Using both arms stabilising behind you on the ground, lift your hips up increasing the weight / pressure through the calves. 3) Using your arm and shoulder strength roll your calves up and down the foam roller. 4) Repeat 10-15 times or until the tenderness or tightness starts to reduce (30-60 seconds).

column3: Calf raises using a Swiss Ball
column6: To strengthen the calves, walkers, runners
column9: 1) Standing against a wall with the Swiss ball behind your back and leaning back slightly into the ball. 2) Draw your shoulders down and engage your core*. 3) Lift up onto both tippy toes and then slowly lower back down. 4) Repeat 10-15 times. 5) Rest for 30 seconds and repeat. (*See 'related exercises)

1) Come onto all fours on the ground with hands flat on the floor under your shoulders. 2) Straighten both legs so that they are straight out behind you. 2) Bend one knee in at the same time pushing the other foot flat to the ground increasing and feeling the stretch in that leg. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat the for the other leg. 5) Then slowly repeat the action of flexing (bending) one knee, then the other in a pedal like motion for 10-15 repetitions.
